instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.U5701: What is U5701? this is the keyboard controller chip that takes the keyboard and trackpad input and turns it into a USB device signal for the machine to process. If replacing a keyboard doesnâ€™t fix an issue with keys not typing, check all traces between keyboard connector and this IC. This chip has programming so it must be replaced from a similar, ideally identical board. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> to keyboard connector
threads.message:
Water damaged <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> got everything working Backlight, Firewire, etc,  Now I need Keyboard/trackpad.  

At connector I have:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> = .745
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 0.0

Is PSOC USB controller <CHIP>U5701</CHIP> supplying <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>?  Could SMC be a part of this to0?

Im going to reflow <CHIP>U5701</CHIP> lightly and see what happens.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> to keyboard connector
threads.message:
Ok and IPD is 

<SIGNAL>PP18V5_S4</SIGNAL> = 0.0  

This is all while booted to USB with no trackpad or keyboard attached.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> to keyboard connector
threads.message: So let me think this out <CHIP>U5805</CHIP> Gets 5v then out of it comes <SIGNAL>PP18V5_S4</SIGNAL> cuz it's a booster?  Right now I have 0.0 on pin 4 of <CHIP>U5805</CHIP>.  Do I need to have things connected to get the right voltages?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> to keyboard connector
threads.message: Going for the Keyboard. Ok Did some reflowing around <CHIP>U5701</CHIP> and touched up <RESISTOR>R7803</RESISTOR> Resistor Now I have 1.85 at Pin 30 for <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>.  On the other side of <RESISTOR>R7803</RESISTOR> I have 3.3 and then 1.85 is that supposed to be that way.  It is a resistor.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> to keyboard connector
threads.message: Ok So 3.3v s4 Fet can have 3.3 or 1.8v?  Maybe that's what's messing me up?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> to keyboard connector
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R7803</RESISTOR> is 0 Ohm so there should be no voltage drop there. <RESISTOR>R7803</RESISTOR> is dead, check for a short first of course. No 3V42 at the connector will be a corroded trace, run a wire.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> to keyboard connector
threads.message: [SOLVED] <RESISTOR>R7803</RESISTOR> ZERO ohm Resistor just decided to start resisting.  Made it a wire. Case closed.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> to keyboard connector
threads.message: 3V42 present on the connector too now? If not then your left shift/alt/ctrl will not work.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> to keyboard connector
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 28111"]3V42 present on the connector too now? If not then your left shift/alt/ctrl will not work.[/QUOTE]

Yes Thank you it was.
